column2: THE DREAM

column2: We have learned to know the origin, nature and function of the dream from the study of children's dreams.

column2: Every time a dream is completely comprehensible to us, it proves to be an hallucinated wish-fulfillment.

column2: Our next task is the investigation and the understanding of this dream distortion.
column3: Our next task is the investigation and the understanding of this dream distortion.

column2: Dream distortion is the thing which makes the dream seem strange and incomprehensible to us.
column3: Dream distortion is the thing which makes the dream seem strange and incomprehensible to us.

column2: We want to know several things about it; firstly, whence it comes, its dynamics; secondly, what it does; and finally, how it does it.
column3: We want to know several things about it; firstly, whence it comes, its dynamics; secondly, what it does; and finally, how it does it.

column2: We can say at this point that dream distortion is the product of the dream work, that is, of the mental functioning of which the dream itself is the conscious symptom.
column3: We can say at this point that dream distortion is the product of the dream work, that is, of the mental functioning of which the dream itself is the conscious symptom.

column2: Let us describe the dream work and trace it back to the forces which work upon it.
column3: Let us describe the dream work and trace it back to the forces which work upon it.

column2: And now I shall ask you to listen to the following dream.
column3: And now I shall ask you to listen to the following dream.

column2: It was recorded by a lady of our profession, and according to her, originated with a highly cultivated and respected lady of advanced age.
column3: It was recorded by a lady of our profession, and according to her, originated with a highly cultivated and respected lady of advanced age.

column2: No analysis of this dream was made.
column3: No analysis of this dream was made.

column2: Our informant remarks that to a psychoanalyst it needs no interpretation.
column3: Our informant remarks that to a psychoanalyst it needs no interpretation.

column2: She stresses the word 'service,' so love services.
column3: She stresses the word 'service,' so love services.

column2: But instead of reaching the chief physician, she finds herself in a large somber room in which there are many officers and army doctors sitting and standing around a long table.
column3: But instead of reaching the chief physician, she finds herself in a large somber room in which there are many officers and army doctors sitting and standing around a long table.

column2: She turns with her proposal to a staff doctor who, after a few words, soon understands her.
column3: She turns with her proposal to a staff doctor who, after a few words, soon understands her.

column2: The words of her speech in the dream are, 'I and numerous other women and girls of Vienna are ready for the soldiers, troops, and officers, without distinction....' Here in the dream follows a murmuring.
column3: The words of her speech in the dream are, 'I and numerous other women and girls of Vienna are ready for the soldiers, troops, and officers, without distinction....' Here in the dream follows a murmuring.

column2: That the idea is, however, correctly understood by those present she sees from the semi-embarrassed, somewhat malicious expressions of the officers.
column3: That the idea is, however, correctly understood by those present she sees from the semi embarrassed, somewhat malicious expressions of the officers.

column2: The lady then continues, 'I know that our decision sounds strange, but we are in bitter earnest.
column3: The lady then continues, 'I know that our decision sounds strange, but we are in bitter earnest.

column2: The soldier in the field is not asked either whether or not he wants to die.' A moment of painful silence follows.

column2: The staff doctor puts his arm around her waist and says, 'Madame, let us assume that it really came to that ...' (murmurs).

column2: At this she realizes with great dismay that she does not know his name.

column2: In going up she hears an officer say, 'That is a tremendous decision irrespective of whether a woman is young or old; all honor to her!'
column3: In going up she hears an officer say, 'That is a tremendous decision irrespective of whether a woman is young or old; all honor to her!'

column2: This dream she repeats twice in the course of a few weeks, with--as the lady notices--quite insignificant and very senseless changes.

column2: This dream corresponds in its structure to a day dream.

column2: It has few gaps, and many of its individual points might have been elucidated as to content through inquiry, which, as you know, was omitted.
column3: It has few gaps, and many of its individual points might have been elucidated as to content through inquiry, which, as you know, was omitted.

column2: The conspicuous and interesting point for us, however, is that the dream shows several gaps, gaps not of recollection, but of original content. In three places the content is apparently obliterated, the speeches in which these gaps occur are interrupted by murmurs.
column3: The conspicuous and interesting point for us, however, is that the dream shows several gaps, gaps not of recollection, but of original content. In three places the content is apparently obliterated, the speeches in which these gaps occur are interrupted by murmurs.

column2: For example, the phrase "services of love," and above all the bits of speech which immediately precede the murmurs, demand a completion which can have but one meaning. If we interpolate these, then the phantasy yields as its content the idea that the dreamer is ready, as an act of patriotic duty, to offer her person for the satisfaction of the erotic desires of the army, officers as well as troops.

column2: I hope you will not consider the expression too anthropomorphically, and picture the dream censor as a severe little manikin who lives in a little brain chamber and there performs his duties; nor should you attempt to localize him too much, to think of a brain center from which his censoring influence emanates, and which would cease with the injury or extirpation of this center.
column3: I hope you will not consider the expression too anthropomorphically, and picture the dream censor as a severe little manikin who lives in a little brain chamber and there performs his duties; nor should you attempt to localize him too much, to think of a brain center from which his censoring influence emanates, and which would cease with the injury or extirpation of this center.

column3: These censored wishes which have attained to a distorted expression in the dream, are above all expressions of a boundless, reckless egoism.

column3: And indeed, the personal ego occurs in every dream to play the major part in each of them, even if it can successfully disguise itself in the manifest content.

column2: The ego which has been freed of all ethical restraints feels itself in accord with all the demands of the sexual striving, with those demands which have long since been condemned by our aesthetic rearing, demands of such a character that they resist all our moral demands for restraint.
column3: The ego which has been freed of all ethical restraints feels itself in accord with all the demands of the sexual striving, with those demands which have long since been condemned by our aesthetic rearing, demands of such a character that they resist all our moral demands for restraint.

column3: The pleasure striving-the libido, as we term it-chooses its objects without inhibitions, and indeed, prefers those that are forbidden.

column3: It chooses not only the wife of another, but, above all, those incestuous objects declared sacred by the agreement of mankind-the mother and sister in the man's case, the father and brother in the woman's.

column3: Do you dare under these circumstances to break a lance for the absence of evil from the psychic constitution of mankind?

column2: It is not our intention to deny the noble strivings of human nature, nor have we ever done anything to deprecate their value.
column3: It is not our intention to deny the noble strivings of human nature, nor have we ever done anything to deprecate their value.

column2: On the contrary, I show you not only the censored evil dream-wishes, but also the censor which suppresses them and renders them unrecognizable.
column3: On the contrary, I show you not only the censored evil dream wishes, but also the censor which suppresses them and renders them unrecognizable.

column2: When, however, we give up this one-sided ethical estimate, we shall surely be able to find a more accurate formula for the relationship of the evil to the good in human nature.
column3: When, however, we give up this one sided ethical estimate, we shall surely be able to find a more accurate formula for the relationship of the evil to the good in human nature.

column2: And thus the matter stands.
column3: And thus the matter stands.

column2: We need not give up the conclusions to which our labors in dream interpretation lead us even though we must consider those conclusions strange.
column3: We need not give up the conclusions to which our labors in dream interpretation lead us even though we must consider those conclusions strange.

column2: Perhaps we can approach their understanding later by another path.
column3: Perhaps we can approach their understanding later by another path.

column2: For the present, let us repeat: dream distortion is a consequence of the censorship practised by accredited tendencies of the ego against those wish-impulses that are in any way shocking, impulses which stir in us nightly during sleep.
column3: For the present, let us repeat: dream distortion is a consequence of the censorship practised by accredited tendencies of the ego against those wish impulses that are in any way shocking, impulses which stir in us nightly during sleep.

column2: Why these wish-impulses come just at night, and whence they come--these are questions which will bear considerable investigation.
column3: Why these wish impulses come just at night, and whence they come-these are questions which will bear considerable investigation.

column2: It would be a mistake, however, to omit to mention, with fitting emphasis, another result of these investigations.
column3: It would be a mistake, however, to omit to mention, with fitting emphasis, another result of these investigations.

column2: The dream wishes which try to disturb our sleep are not known to us, in fact we learn of them first through the dream interpretation.
column3: The dream wishes which try to disturb our sleep are not known to us, in fact we learn of them first through the dream interpretation.

column2: Therefore, they may be described as "at that time" unconscious in the sense above defined.
column3: Therefore, they may be described as "at that time" unconscious in the sense above defined.

column2: But we can go beyond this and say that they are more than merely "at that time" unconscious.
column3: But we can go beyond this and say that they are more than merely "at that time" unconscious.

column2: The dreamer to be sure denies their validity, as we have seen in so many cases, even after he has learned of their existence by means of the interpretation.
column3: The dreamer to be sure denies their validity, as we have seen in so many cases, even after he has learned of their existence by means of the interpretation.

column2: The situation is then repeated which we first encountered in the interpretation of the tongue slip "hiccough" where the toastmaster was outraged and assured us that neither then nor ever before had he been conscious of disrespectful impulse toward his chief.
column3: The situation is then repeated which we first encountered in the interpretation of the tongue slip "hiccough" where the toastmaster was outraged and assured us that neither then nor ever before had he been conscious of disrespectful impulse toward his chief.

column2: This is repeated with every interpretation of a markedly distorted dream, and for that reason attains a significance for our conception.
column3: This is repeated with every interpretation of a markedly distorted dream, and for that reason attains a significance for our conception.

column2: We are now prepared to conclude that there are processes and tendencies in the psychic life of which one knows nothing at all, has known nothing for some time, might, in fact, perhaps never have known anything.
column3: We are now prepared to conclude that there are processes and tendencies in the psychic life of which one knows nothing at all, has known nothing for some time, might, in fact, perhaps never have known anything.
